# The Discount Rate {background-color="#1c4982"}

## Why Discount the Future?

- In most environmental policies, **costs/benefits often occur at different times**
- Converting everything to **real (inflation-adjusted) dollars** handles inflation‚Äîbut **not time preference**
- People (and societies) often **prefer benefits now** (investment opportunity, **uncertainty**, **impatience**)
- Therefore we apply **discounting** to compare **future** and **present** values on a common basis

::: callout-note
- **Idea:** *$100 today* can be worth the same as *$200 ten years from now* at an appropriate discount rate.
:::



## Present Value (PV) Formula

Let $X_n$ be a cost/benefit received in $n$ years and $r$ the **discount rate**:

$$
\text{PV}(X_n) \;=\; \frac{X_n}{(1+r)^{\,n}}
$$

- **Further in time** ($n\uparrow$) ‚Üí PV **falls**  
- **Higher discount rate** ($r\uparrow$) ‚Üí PV **falls**

::: callout-tip
- **Examples (for $X_n = \$100$)**  
  - $r=3\%, n=10 \Rightarrow \text{PV}=\$74.41$  
  - $r=7\%, n=10 \Rightarrow \text{PV}=\$50.83$
:::






## How Fast Does PV Decline?

- **High $r$** greatly devalues distant impacts  
  - $r=7\%, n=50\Rightarrow \text{PV}=\$3.39$ for \$100  
  - $r=10\%, n=50\Rightarrow \text{PV}=\$0.85$
- **Small changes in $r$** matter a lot over long horizons  
  - After **100 years**, PV at **1%** is about **7√ó** the PV at **3%**

# Choosing the Discount Rate: Two Approaches {background-color="#1c4982"}

## Why Discount the Future?


In both **market-based** and **social** approaches, the **discount rate** answers a fundamental question:  

> *At what rate should society be compensated in the future for giving up one unit of consumption today so that overall well-being is preserved?*

- This rate reflects how we **value the future relative to the present**, whether through:
  - **Ethical principles** about intergenerational welfare, or
  - **Observed market behavior** (opportunity cost of capital)


## Social Discount Rate (SDR)

<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

$$
\text{SDR} = \rho + \varepsilon \cdot g
$$

<div style="display:block; margin:-20px;"></div>

- $\rho$: **pure rate of time preference** ‚Äî captures **impatience** or preference for present welfare over future welfare  
- $\varepsilon$: **elasticity of marginal utility of consumption** ‚Äî measures how quickly **the extra satisfaction (utility)** from consumption **declines as people become richer**  
  - When people are **poor**, an extra dollar raises happiness a lot  
  - When people are **richer**, an extra dollar adds little  
  - **Inequality aversion:** a higher $\varepsilon$ means society is more sensitive to inequality across generations
  <!-- - **Inequality aversion:** a higher $\varepsilon$ means society values **additional income for poorer generations** more than for richer ones   -->
- $g$: **growth rate of real consumption** ‚Äî the expected pace of income growth over time  
<!-- - **Wealth effect:** together, $\varepsilon$ and $g$ determine how **fast overall welfare grows** as society becomes wealthier -->



## 1Ô∏è‚É£ Ethical (Prescriptive) Approach

> ‚ÄúWhat *should* be the fair tradeoff between present and future welfare?‚Äù

- Sets parameters based on **ethical principles** of **intergenerational fairness**, not on market behavior  
  - $\rho$: very low (‚âà 0‚Äì0.1%) ‚Üí future welfare valued almost equally to present welfare  
  - $\varepsilon$: reflects **inequality aversion** ‚Äî society places **less value on extra income for richer future generations**  
  - $g$: assumes **modest long-run growth** (e.g., 1‚Äì1.5%), consistent with sustainability concerns  
- **Result:** Low SDR (‚âà 1‚Äì2%) ‚Üí **greater weight on future generations** and **stronger justification for early climate action**




## 2Ô∏è‚É£  Market-Based (Descriptive) Approach

::: callout-note
The **Opportunity Cost of Capital** is the **return forgone** when spending \$1 today on a project, instead of **investing that same \$1 in the best available alternative** (for example, in private capital markets or government bonds).
:::

<!-- - Reflects **how markets actually discount the future**, not how we *should* -->

- Set $r \approx$ **low-risk market return** (e.g., government bonds or average real return on capital)  
- **Logic:** Funds spent today could have been **invested** ‚Äî the **opportunity cost of capital** determines the appropriate $r$  
- **Idea:** Society‚Äôs **time preference** between present and future consumption is *revealed* through **saving, investment, and consumption decisions**, as reflected in **observed market returns** and **long-run economic growth**.
- **Caveat:** Market rates **change over time**  
  - Very low in the 2020s; very high in the early 1980s  



## üí∞ Market-Based (Descriptive) Approach

> ‚ÄúHow do markets *actually* value the future?‚Äù

- Sets parameters based on **observed economic behavior**, not ethical judgments  
  - $\rho$: **higher** (‚âà 1‚Äì2%) ‚Äî reflects society‚Äôs **revealed time preference** in saving and investment decisions  
  - $\varepsilon$: inferred from **market data** ‚Äî captures how people trade off **consumption and risk** over time  
  - $g$: assumes **stronger long-run growth** (e.g., 2%), consistent with **historical productivity trends**  
- **Result:** Higher SDR (‚âà 4‚Äì5%) ‚Üí **less weight on distant future impacts** and supports  relatively **gradual, cost-efficient mitigation og GHG**

## Discounting Climate Change ‚Äî Two Lenses

| Feature | **Ethical** | **Market-based** |
|:--|:--|:--|
| Approach |  How we ought to value the future |  How markets actually value the future |
| $\rho$ | $0.1\%$ | $1.5\%$ |
| $\varepsilon$ | $1.0$ | $1.5$ |
| $g$ | $1.3\%$ | $2.0\%$ |
| Resulting rate | **$\approx 1.4\%$** | **$\approx 4.25\%$** |
| Policy implication | Immediate, large cuts | Gradual mitigation path |

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

::: callout-note
Although Nordhaus assumes a higher $\varepsilon$ (greater inequality aversion),  
his larger $\rho$ and $g$ dominate ‚Äî resulting in a **higher overall discount rate**.
:::


## üìä Policy Relevance & Ethics

- **2018 Survey of Economists:**  
  - Mean = **2.3%**, Median = **2.0%** (real SDR for intergenerational global projects)  
  - **68%** of economists recommend a rate between **1‚Äì3%**  
  - **Trend:** Steady shift **toward lower discount rates** since 2001, reflecting greater concern for long-term welfare  
- **High $r$** ‚Üí prioritizes the **present**, discounting future impacts heavily  
- **Low $r$** ‚Üí gives greater **weight to future generations**  
- In **environmental cost‚Äìbenefit analysis** (e.g., climate policy):  
  - **Costs occur now**, **benefits arise later** ‚Üí a **lower $r$** supports **stronger environmental protection**  
- There is no single ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù rate ‚Äî analysts should be **transparent**, **justify their assumptions**, and **test results through sensitivity analysis**.
